metadata.title: Environmental transformation and nano-toxicity of engineered nano-particles (ENPs) in aquatic and terrestrial organisms

sections.text:
KEYWORDS Engineered nano-particles; environmental safety; nano-toxicity; transformation pathways
CONTACT Balal Yousaf balal@ustc.edu.cn, lordbalal@hotmail.com CAS-Key Laboratory of Crust-Mantle Materials and the Environments, School of Earth and Space Sciences, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, PR China; J€org Rinklebe rinklebe@uni-wuppertal.de School of Architecture and Civil Engineering, Institute of Foundation Engineering, Water- and Waste-Management, Soil- and GroundwaterManagement, University of Wuppertal, Pauluskirchstraße 7, 42285 Wuppertal, Germany. Color versions of one or more of the figures in the article can be found online at www.tandfonline.com/best. 2019 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nanotechnology involves the manipulation of matter at individual atomic, molecular and sub-molecular levels ( 100 nm). ENPs are the building blocks of engineered nano-materials (ENMs), having novel physico-chemical characteristics such as high surface area to volume ratio, more reactivity, exceptional conductivity and optical properties compared to their bulk counterparts due to large number of surface reactive atoms (John et al., 2017; Lopez-Serrano et al., 2014). ENMs can be classified on the basis of morphology, surface chemistry and core chemical composition (Baalousha, Lead, & Ju-Nam, 2011). Broadly, the ENMs are classified into carbon-based materials, metal and metal oxide, quantum dots (QDs) and organic polymers based on the core chemical composition (Figure 1). In recent years the applications of nanotechnology has grown progressively in many sectors including agriculture, automotive, cosmetics, construction, electronics, environment, food, home appliances, medicine, petroleum, printing, renewable energies, sports and fitness, textile and among others (Bhatt & Tripathi, 2011; Bystrzejewska-Piotrowska, Golimowski, & Urban, 2009; Goswami et al., 2017; Holden et al., 2014; Suresh, Pelletier, & Doktycz, 2013). It is a multibillion dollar industry currently having 8495 nano-enabled products in the market produced by 2070 companies from 56 different countries worldwide (www.product.statnano.com). According to recent HTF market report, global nanotechnology market value is likely to exceed 125 billion US$ by 2024 (HTF Market Report, 2018). In parallel, global production of ENMs was estimated between 2680,000 to 3180,000 metric tons in 2010 and increasing at a
rate of 25% per annum since that time (Younis, El-Fawal, & Serp, 2018). In order to meet the ever-escalating demand for nano-enabled products, unrestricted massive quantities of ENMs are likely to generate ENPs as a new category of emerging potential environmental contaminants. ENPs are released into the environment during the production process of nanoenabled products, their use phase and life cycle end (Nowack et al., 2012; Vance et al., 2015). Once ENPs are dispersed in the different environmental compartments (air, water, and soil), these are driven away from their pristine nano-state through various physical, chemical and biological transformation processes (Lowry, Gregory, Apte, & Lead, 2012). ENPs properties including, size, shape, surface functionality, in addition to environmental conditions, govern these environmental processes and ultimately altered the fate and behavior of ENPs (Amde, Liu, Tan, & Bekana, 2017). For instance, Ag ENPs sulfidation followed by oxidation process changed the ENPs degree of aggregation, surface reactivity, charge, and potential to release toxic metal ions (Agþ) (Brunetti et al., 2015; Lowry, Espinasse, et al., 2012). Similarly, the interaction of ENPs with natural organic matter (NOM) and extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) analogs to protein corona in mammals altered the ENPs persistence and toxicity (Adeleye & Keller, 2016; Cornelis, Hund-Rinke, Kuhlbusch, van den Brink, & Nickel, 2014; Domingos, Rafiei, Monteiro, Khan, & Wilkinson, 2013). Thus, humans and other organisms are exposed to environmentally transformed ENPs rather than the pristine particles incorporated in nano-enabled products. Moreover, the atmosphere release of ENPs has implications on global climate change through interaction with various gaseous pollutants (John et al., 2017). The carbon based nanomaterials such as graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) has tendency to combine with the different gases and water vapors and change which change their reactivity (Yu et al., 2015). Recently, Zhao group (Zhao, Su arez, Tran, Puntes, & Riediker, 2019) has found that surface coating of low volatile organic compound (LVOC) vapors on Ag ENPs modify the ENPs surface functionality and enhanced the production of ROS. The innovative economic potential of ENPs has serious concern for human health and ecosystem safety due to their unique nano-scale properties. Recent studies have indicated the negative impacts of different ENPs on living organisms from molecular level to the whole organism in microbes, plants and animals including human beings primarily through the overproduction of ROS (Fajardo, Sacc a, Costa, Nande, & Martin, 2014; Mustafa & Komatsu, 2016; Wu et al., 2018). Other toxicity mechanisms involved the dissolution and release of toxic ions, as well as ENPs physical interaction (Das et al., 2018; Jin et al., 2014; Zhao et al., 2015). Concerns
over the safety of ENPs have also been rising due to their bio-accumulation potential and trophic level transfer in food web through the consumption of contaminated food in addition of direct environmental exposure (Tangaa, Selck, Winther-Nielsen, & Khan, 2016). Therefore, timely and integrated review of current knowledge about the environmental transformation and eco-nano-toxicity of ENPs released from various consumer products is needed. Moreover, it is also crucial to monitor the nano-waste in the environment and adopt certain sustainable approaches to obtain maximum benefits of nanotechnology with minimum negative outcomes. In the current review, we discuss the ENPs mobility, and bioavailability to different ecological receptors. The possible mechanisms of nano-toxicity in microbes, plants, and animals including mammals have been discussed. We also proposed certain integrated and eco-friendly strategies for the remediation, and handling of nano-wastes. Finally, we identify key knowledge gaps that need to be considered in future ecological risk assessments studies to prevent the ENPs irreversible ecological damage.

sections.heading: 2. Interaction and impacts of ENPs on microbial community
sections.text: Microbial communities in the natural environment are among the most abundant and diversified organisms. These are crucial for normal ecosystem functioning as these perform variety of ecosystem services such as nutrient cycling, organic matter (OM) decomposition and degradation of toxic pollutants (Ren et al., 2018; Soliveres et al., 2016). ENPs interaction with microbes alters their community structure and dynamic functioning. In the recent years, a number of studies have been conducted to explore the possible toxicological effects of organic and inorganic ENPs to different microorganisms (bacteria, algae, protozoa, and fungi) inhabiting in aquatic and terrestrial habitats (Deng, Cheng, et al., 2017; Jin et al., 2014). ENPs are bioavailable to microbes either by dissolution and release of toxic ions or directly in nano-form. Microbial toxicity induced by ENPs dependent on the cell intake pathway via endocytosis or phagocytosis (Von Moos, Bowen, & Slaveykova, 2014). The cell membrane damage caused by physical interaction and generation of ROS inside the organisms by the chemical process is the primary cytotoxicity mechanism (Figure 2). Studies have revealed that ENPs can produce severe perturbations in micro-biota. ENPs have an impact on microbes both directly by producing oxidative stress and changing the bio-availability of nutrients or indirectly after interaction with naturally occurring organic compounds (e.g., NOM) and toxic pollutants, thereby alleviating or amplifying the toxicity (Dinesh, Anandaraj, Srinivasan, & Hamza, 2012). The toxic effects of different ENPs to microbial community are presented in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Nano-toxicity of ENPs to bacteria
sections.text:
Bacteria are microscopic, usually single celled that thrive in diverse environments. They perform important services in the environment such as fermentation and decomposition processes. The ease of culturing along with ecological importance has made the bacterial community an important group of organisms for eco-nano-toxicity studies. Most commonly used bacteria for nano-toxicity studies belong to genus Bacillus, Pseudomonas (Doody, Wang, Bais, & Jin, 2016; Fajardo et al., 2014), Escherichia (Kaweeteerawat et al., 2015), and nitrifying bacteria (Wu et al., 2018). Some ENPs are incorporated in consumer products due to their antimicrobial activities such as in medical devices, surface coatings, textiles goods and food packaging materials (Hoek, 2010; Mitrano, Limpiteeprakan, Babel, & Nowack, 2016). The degradation of such ENPs incorporated products with time release the product nanoparticles in the environment which upon interaction with bacteria affect their growth, development and other ecosystem services (Fajardo et al., 2014; Soliveres et al., 2016). For instance, Ag ENPs exposure to Gram-positive (Bacillus subtilis) and Gram-negtive (Escherichia coli) bacteria at environmentally relevant concentration (5mg L 1) for 8 h inhibited their growth and changed the growth kinetics

(Doody et al., 2016). Su group (2015) has found that CuO ENPs upon contact with denitrifying (Paracoccus denitrificans) bacterium at 0.25mg L 1 concentration reduced the organism nitrogen removal efficiency by downregulating GtsB protein and suppressing the expression of key electrontransport-proteins. Other metal oxide ENPs interaction with Azotobacter, nitrifying, phosphorus-and potassium-solubilizing bacteria decreased the microbes growth rate with the inhibition of enzymatic activities (Chai et al., 2015; Wu et al., 2018). Carbon-based ENMs (SWCNTs and graphene oxide) inactivate the Gram-positive and Gram-positive bacteria by cell membrane damage and effluxing cytoplasmic materials (Akhavan & Ghaderi, 2010; Jin et al., 2014). For example, soil born exposure of SWCNTs in concentration range between 0.03 to 1mg g 1 reduced the biomass of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria as well as alter the microbial community composition identified through phospholipid fatty acid profile (Jin et al., 2014). ENPs normally attach to bacterial plasma/cell membrane by electrostatic interaction and disturb the membrane integrity. Generally inside the cell toxicity is induced with the trigger of oxidative stress, that is the production of free radicals mainly ROS, protein deactivation and gene expression alteration (Fajardo et al., 2014; Kaweeteerawat et al., 2015). The toxicological effects of various ENPs to different bacterial species are summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nano-toxicity of ENPs to algae
sections.text:
Algae are another group of microbes widely employed in eco-toxicological studies. These are located at bottom of the food web and knowledge about ENPs uptake, bio-accumulation and toxicity in the primary producer is essential as ENPs can be transferred through the food chain to other organisms situated at higher trophic level (Lee, Yoon, Shin, & An, 2015; Pakrashi, Dalai, Chandrasekaran, & Mukherjee, 2014). Studies have shown that primary interaction and uptake of ENPs in different algae species happen through the cell wall. Zhao et al. (2016) upon exposure of CuO ENPs up to 200mg L 1 concentration has identified the bioaccumulation of these ENPs in green algae Chlorella pyrenoidosa followed the adhesion of particles with cells and internalization by endocytosis process. About 50% cellular growth inhibition in green algae Dunaliella tertiolecta and marine diatom Skeletonema costatum were observed in an artificial seawater medium containing silver ENPs at 0.4–6.4mg L 1 concentration (Gambardella et al., 2015). The main detrimental effects on algae cells after their exposure to diverse ENPs are cell membrane damage, reduction in chlorophyll content and photosynthetic activity, mitochondrial depolarization, oxidative stress, growth inhibition, gene expression alteration and
proteomic profile change (Deng, Cheng, et al., 2017; Schiavo, Oliviero, Miglietta, Rametta, & Manzo, 2016; Zhao et al., 2016). The process of ENPs biomagnification occurs when algal biomass containing ENPs is eaten by higher trophic level consumers. Lee group (2015) has confirmed the one-way flow of Au-nanoparticles in the aquatic food chain from primary producers Chlamydomonas reinhardtii and Euglena gracilis to the primary consumer Daphnia magna. When a uni-cellular green algae Chlorella ellipsoides infested cells with aluminum oxide (Al2O3) ENPs at 20–120mg L 1 concentration for 48 h were fed to a water flea Ceriodaphnia dubia, the ENPs bioaccumulated and biomagnification were observed in daphnids (Pakrashi, Dalai, et al., 2014). The bioaccumulated ENPs in primary produces are potentially toxic to the higher trophic level consumer who used these producers as a diet source.

sections.heading: 2.3. Nano-toxicity of ENPs to protozoa
sections.text:
Protozoa are single-celled, eukaryotic organisms inhabiting at damp places. These are either free-living or parasites on other organisms use organic carbon as an energy source. Ecotoxicologists extensively studied the protozoa because of their regulatory role in microbial community structure and function through bacterial ingestion and digestion (Ghafari et al., 2008). Tetrahymena thermophila are valuable model protozoa for the assessment of ENPs toxic effects. Data showing the impacts of various ENPs on different protozoa species is represented in Table 1. ENPs uptake and accumulation in protozoa food vacuole mainly occur through endocytosis and phagocytosis mediated pathways (Ud-Daula, Pfister, & Schramm, 2013; Werlin et al., 2011). ENPs induced toxicity in protozoa through the upregulation of metallothionein genes (Juganson et al., 2017), lowering in the membrane fluidity by changing fatty acid composition (Mortimer, Kasemets, Vodovnik, Marins Ek-Logar, & Kahru, 2011), oxidative stress, reduction in viability and motility (Gupta, Senapati, Dhawan, & Shanker, 2017). Casein coated Ag ENPs exposure to Tetrahymena thermophile at 20mg L 1 concentration for 24 h induced the oxidative stress and up regulate the metallothionein protein. Protozoa have also been tested successfully to evaluate the trophic level transfer of ENPs through the food chain. Werlin et al. (2011) has examined the cadmium accumulation and biomagnification from CdSe QDs in Tetrahymena thermophile with the ingestion of QDs loaded Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria. A load of cadmium in protozoa predator was about 5 times higher than the prey organism (bacteria). This biomagnification was due to protozoa higher efficacy of the phagocytosis process and apparently QDs more stability (Werlin et al., 2011). Further, the QDs are bioavailable to higher trophic level organisms
as protozoa do not undergo lysis. In vivo bio-imaging of ENPs confirmed their three-level trophic transfer in food web from protozoa-(Astasia longa)-to-zooplankton (Moina macrocopa)-to-fish (Danio rerio) (Lee & An, 2015).

sections.heading: 2.4. Nano-toxicity of ENPs to fungi
sections.text: Fungi are the dominant decomposers inhabiting in freshwater, marine and terrestrial ecosystems. These play a vital role in the circulation of nutrients and energy in the biosphere with the decay of dead plants and animals (Li, Wang, Bian, Guo, & Cai, 2016). Thus, to ensure the normal ecosystem services, it is crucial to understand the potential toxic effects of ENPs to fungi. Data (Table 1) about ENPs impacts on different species of fungus shows that different toxic effects are induced after the absorption of ENPs through the cell wall. Studies have shown the impact of ENPs on fungi is linked with the cell membrane damage, inhibition of growth, reduced cell density, cytoplasm blebbing, cell death and eventually loss in decomposition activity with reduction in lignocellulolytic enzymes production (Han et al., 2012; Shah et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2018). When Saccharomyces cerevisiae is exposed to 40–1000mg L 1 cadmium sulfide QDs (CdS QDs) for 24 h, many genes are reprogramed particularly related to abiotic stresses, metabolic pathways, mitochondrion organization, transport and repairing of DNA (Marmiroli et al., 2016). In most of the aforementioned microbial nano-toxicity studies the exposure concentration of different ENPs is quite high (mg L 1/or mg kg 1) than the predicted concentrations (ng L 1/pg L 1/mg kg 1) of ENPs in various technical (sewage treatment sludge, sewage treatment effulent, waste incinerated bottom and fly ash) and natural (soils, sediments, surface and ground water) compartments (Garner, Suh, & Keller, 2017; Giese et al., 2018; Gottschalk et al., 2015). But, in natural environment microbes are continuously exposed to low concentration of ENPs for longer period of time comparative to nano-toxicity studies where exposure level is high and duration is short.

sections.heading: 3. Phyto-transformation of ENPs and their toxicity mechanism
sections.text:
Most likely exposure pathway of ENPs to terrestrial plants is the application of sewage sludge or solid bio-waste to agricultural lands. Solid biowaste is a rich source of nutrients which is an alternative of costly synthetic fertilizers to improve the soil fertility and productivity. For instance, in the US, about 60% solid bio-waste is applied directly to the agricultural fields every year. This solid bio-waste consists of a substantial amount of ENPs,
as according to an estimate approximately 50% ENPs in WWTPs (wastewater treatment plants) ends up in soil (Keller & Lazareva, 2014). Other sources of ENPs exposure to plants are the atmospheric deposition (John et al., 2017), nano-particles soil application for remediation purpose (Farkas et al., 2015; Nunes et al., 2017), nano-formulated agrochemicals use (Duhan et al., 2017), surface runoff, and wastewater irrigation (Pradas del Real et al., 2016). The negtive effects of ENPs to various plants species is described in Table 2.

sections.heading: 3.1. Uptake, distribution and biotransformation of ENPs in plant
sections.text:
ENPs present in the environment upon interaction with plants can be internalized in plant tissues either through roots (root tips, suberin-coated roots, lateral roots, cortex, root junctions or wounds) or above ground parts (epidermis, stomata, trichomes, stigma, and hydathodes) (Rizwan et al., 2017). Several physiological and chemical process including cellular signaling, membranes recycling and regulations are involved for ENPs uptake and translocation in plants (Figure 3). Cell wall, a porous network of polysaccharides is the primary barriers in plant cells with the size exclusion limit (SEL) of 5–20 nm allow the acquisition of smaller size ENPs along with water by active/passive transport (Zhao et al., 2012). Once ENPs have internalized in the cell, these transport between cells through cylindrical plasmodesmata channels of 40 nm SEL. Further transport of ENPs may accomplish through endocytosis process and apoplastic/symplastic transport pathway to different plant tissues (Li, Zheng, et al., 2016; Pradas del Real et al., 2017). Translocation of ENPs from root-to-shoot occurs through xylem in case of root-mediated uptake, whereas stomata uptake via aerial exposure causes the phloem based distribution in plants (Ma et al., 2017). Larger size ENPs than the SELs of cell walls, intracellular plasmodesmata channels, and Casparian bands usually internalized through structural modification in cell walls, cuticular interaction or at the site of lateral roots development, where the Casparian band is not fully formed (Wang, Lombi, Zhao, & Kopittke, 2016). Moreover, during the germination stage of plant growth, parenchymatous intercellular spaces and aquaporins (AQPs) gated channels are involved in regulating the plant uptake of ENPs (Miralles, Church, & Harris, 2012). ENPs after cellular internalization accumulate in plant roots or translocate to aerial parts depending on the plant species, ENPs size, type, exposure concentration and duration (Iannone, Groppa, de Sousa, Fern andez van Raap, & Benavides, 2016; Xiong et al., 2017). Knowledge about ENPs localization in subcellular organelles as well as speciation and biotransformation inside plants is critical to understand their nano-impact. ENPs in plant subcellular components. In Medicago sativa L. mercaptopropanoic acid QDs (CdSe/ZnS) particles (4–6 nm) localized inside the nucleus and cytoplasmic regions (Santos et al., 2010). Cu(II) ENPs accumulate in the root cell vacuoles and bio-transformed into different copper species (Cu2O, Cu2S, CuS, CuSO4, Cu2(OH)PO4, Cu-acetate, Cu-citrate, and Cucysteine) upon interaction with biological ligands and even can be reduced to Cu (I) in plant tissues (Dimkpa, Latta, et al., 2013; Yuan, He, Huang, Hua, & Sheng, 2016; Zhao, Ren, et al., 2017). Reducing substances (e.g., ascorbic acids) and organic acids (e.g., citric acids) at nano-bio-interface inside Cucumis sativus roots promote the dissolution of CeO2 (IV) ENPs. The subsequent bio-transformed cerium phosphate (CePO4) needlelike crystals accumulate in roots and cerium carboxylates (Ce(CH3COO)3) translocate into shoot portion (Ma, Zhang, Zhang, He, Zhang, et al., 2015; Zhang, Petersen, et al., 2012). Cerium ENPs accumulate as Ce-acetate, Cecarbonate, Ce-sulfate, Ce-hydroxide in soybean (Glycine max L.) plant, and Zn transform into O-bound Zn compounds (acetate, oxalate, nitrate, and citrate) (Hernandez-Viezcas et al., 2013). Other bio-transformed Zn species has also been reported in the roots, stem, and leaves of wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), Cowpea (Vigna unguiculata) and maize (Zea mays L.) (Dimkpa, Latta, et al., 2013; Lv et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2013). TiO2 rutile phase distributes in the aboveground tissues and anatase particles remain in roots without any dissolution or biotransformation in Cucumis sativus plants. Mesoporous silica nano-particles (MSPs) localized in the cell chloroplast after cellular internalization (Sun et al., 2014). Most abundantly used ferromagnetic Fe3O4 ENPs bio-transformed into ferrous sulfate and ferric citrate in the pumpkin and perennial rye grass roots without translocation to other plant tissues (Wang et al., 2011). Rare earth elements based ENPs (Ytterbium and Lanthanum) have affinity to combine with phosphate or carboxylic group in cucumber (Cucumis sativus), subsequent transformed YbPO4 deposit in root cytoplasm and LaPO4 or lanthanum carboxylates in
Figure 3. Schematic diagram of ENPs exposure pathways to plants (a), symplastic and apoplastic transport of NPs into plant cells (b) and cellular toxicity mechanism of ENPs. Adapted from Du et al. (2017), P erez-de-Luque (2017) and Hatami et al. (2016).
the stem and leaves (Ma, Zhang, Zhang, He, Li, et al., 2015; Zhang, Ma, Zhang, He, Guo, et al., 2012). It has been noted that in wheat roots tissue silver ENPs form complex with thiol-containing molecules followed by oxidative dissolution (Pradas del Real et al., 2017). Intracellular bio-transformation and speciation of ENPs in plants mediate their toxicity at physiomorphological and molecular levels.

sections.heading: 3.2. Phytotoxicity at physio-morphological levels
sections.text:
A large number of nano-phyto-toxicity studies are currently available showing the positive or negative effects of ENPs in plants (Table 2). In most cases plants show the hormetic response to ENPs application; low dose simulation/beneficial and high dose inhibitory or toxic effects (Bradfield, Kumar, White, & Ebbs, 2017; Iannone et al., 2016; Khodakovskaya et al., 2013). ENPs interaction with plants induces several physiological and morphological changes including impaired seed germination, plant growth inhibition, reduced biomass production, imbalanced nutrients and alteration in photosynthesis and transpiration rates (Bandyopadhyay et al., 2015; Ma et al., 2016; Rizwan et al., 2017). Intrinsic (system/environment independent; particle size distribution, specific surface area, particle shape, hydrophobicity, chemical composition, redox potential and band gap) and extrinsic (system/environment dependent; density, dustiness, zeta potential, agglomeration rate, dissolution rate and solubility) properties of ENPs determine their nature of interaction and toxicity to different plant species (Wang et al., 2016). Other factors in addition of ENPs properties that influence the nano-phyto-toxicity are the plant type (species), growth stage (germination, flowering, fruiting), culture media (soil or hydroponics) and exposure concentration of ENPs to plants. Cucumber and wheat plants fresh biomass and growth reduced with the waterborne exposure of Ag2S ENPs at an environmentally relevant concentration of 10mg L 1 (Wang et al., 2017). Cu ENPs (10–100 nm) application in soil at rates of 20 or 80mg kg 1 decreased ( 50%) Coriandrum sativum seed germination and also negatively impacted the nutritional quality by reducing macro-(Ca, Mg and S) and micro (B, Mn, Zn) elements content (Zuverza-Mena et al., 2015). During the life cycle of Zea mays L., soil-to-root uptake of ZnO ENPs at 800mg kg 1 exposure level reduces photosynthesis rate (12%), stomatal conductance (15%), chlorophyll content (10%) and eventually economical yield (49%) (Zhao et al., 2015). Rico et al. (2013) reported that 500mg kg 1 soil exposure of CeO2 ENPs to wheat plants during their entire life cycle affected the nutritional quality of wheat grains by modifying the uptake of minerals and assimilation into protein (prolamin, glutelin), fatty acid (lauric and valeric acids) and starch. Generally, the above
mentioned ENPs phyto-toxicity may occur through following five processes: (1) toxic ions release after partial dissolution, (2) shape or/sizedependent mechanical damage and membranes pore plugging, (3) redoxcycling and Fenton mediated ROS production, (4) binding interaction with proteins (protein-corona) and other biomolecules, (5) biomolecules catalytic oxidation (Yanik & Vardar, 2018).

sections.heading: 3.3. Biochemical pathways of toxicity: oxidative stress and anti-oxidative defense system
sections.text:
Biochemical processes in plants during life cycle produces reactive oxygen intermediates (1O2, O2 , H2O2, and HO ) normally called ROS. These ROS are the key signaling transduction molecules in the response of biotic and abiotic environmental stresses and also involved in cellular metabolism, growth, development, and programed cell death (Jagadissgupta & Igamberdiev, 2015). During normal cellular functioning ROS are formed either through redox chain reactions or as metabolic byproducts and localized in different cell organelles such as in chloroplast, mitochondria, and peroxisome (del R ıo, 2015). ENPs mediate photo-toxicity mainly through overproduction of ROS, which could cause protein oxidation, cellular DNA damage, electrolyte leakage with cell membrane lipid peroxidation and eventually apoptotic cell death (Mukherjee et al., 2014; Mustafa & Komatsu, 2016). Plants innate antioxidant defense machinery avoids biomolecules oxidative damage by scavenging the excessive amount of these reactive species with housekeeping enzymatic and non-enzymatic anti-oxidants (del R ıo, 2015). Enzymatic antioxidants including ascorbate peroxidase (APOX), catalase (CAT), dehydroascorbate reductase (DHAR), guaiacol peroxidase (GPX), glutathione peroxidase (GPOX), glutathione reductase (GR), glutathione S-transferase (GST), mono-dehydroascorbate reductase (MDHAR), peroxidase (POD) and superoxide dismutase (SOD) helps to maintain the ROS homeostasis in plants (Ma, White, Dhankher, & Xing, 2015). In order to overcome the oxidative stress, specific antioxidant defense enzyme quenches a certain type of ROS through charge transfer mechanism. As a front line of defense CAT, GPOX, and SOD suppresses the formation of reactive oxygen intermediates by rapid neutralization of free radicals. These enzymes catalyze the dismutation of superoxide radical (O2
) into H2O2 and hydroperoxides and eventually breakdown them to harmless molecules (alcohol/H2O and O2) (Ighodaro & Akinloye, 2018). However during this process produced H2O2 initiate metal ions (Fe
2þ and Cu2þ) catalyzed Fenton reaction and can generate highly toxic reactive oxygen intermediate HO , which cannot be detoxified with any known antioxidant enzymes (Ma, White, et al., 2015). As a function of 150 lg L 1
exposure of CuO ENPs, 57% more production of reactive oxygen intermediate HO has been reported in duckweed (Lemna minor L.) chloroplasts (Yue et al., 2018). The simplified process involved in HO formation through Fenton reaction is explained in the following equations: The first step during this reaction is the reduction of ferric ions into ferrous,
Fe3þ þ O2 ! Fe2þ þ O2 (1) This step is called the Fenton reaction: Fe2þ þ H2O2 ! Fe3þ þ OH þ HO (2) Moreover, alternatively through Haber–Weiss reaction hydrogen peroxide can also react with reactive oxygen intermediate (O2 ) to form highly reactive oxygen intermediate HO , expressed in Eq. (3).
O2 þ H2O2 ! HO þ OH þ O2 (3)
Normally, ENPs induces oxidative stress in a dose-dependent manner and levels of different antioxidant enzymes indicate the activity of the plant defense system in the response of nano-toxicity. Measurement of total ROS by confocal laser scanning microscopy and H2O2, O2
through histochemical staining in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana grown in CeO2 and In2O3 containing medium indicated the oxidative stress. Moreover, the elevated activities of SOD, CAT, APOX, POD, GST, and GR explain the activation of plant defense system in the response of ENPs accumulation in plant tissues (Ma et al., 2016). Wheat plants antioxidant machinery (CAT, APOX, GPOX, SOD) successfully deactivate the reactive oxygen intermediates (H2O2 or O2 ) generated by magnetic iron oxide at 5–20mg L 1 exposure level of ENPs (Iannone et al., 2016). In peas (Pisum sativum L.), ZnO ENPs decreased the plant chlorophyll content with 61% more production of H2O2 and two-fold high lipid peroxidation, an indicator of cell membranes damage, at 500mg kg 1 concentration of ENPs as compared to control. The activities of APOX and CAT were also down-regulated in plants (Mukherjee et al., 2014). Similarly, Ag and CuO ENPs at exposure levels of 1mg L 1 and 1.5mM respectively, caused the severe oxidative burst in rice plants with the elevation of hydrogen peroxide and malondialdehyde (MDA) level, a biomarker of lipid oxidation. Moreover, the reduction in total chlorophyll and carotenoids contents was also observed (Nair & Chung, 2014a; Shaw & Hossain, 2013). Even the more production of antioxidants APOX, SOD and the higher ratio of reduced glutathione (GSH) to oxidized glutathione (GSSG) in nano-treated plants are unable to scavenge reactive oxygen intermediates and prevent oxidative damage (Shaw & Hossain, 2013). Recently, Hao et al. (2018) has observed the
oxidative stress induced cytotoxicity in plants with shrinkage and deformation of roots cortical cells in response of 50mg kg 1 exposure of carbonbased nano-materials (fullerene-C60, MWCNTs (multiwalled carbon nanotubes)) through SOD (Fe-SOD, Mn-SOD, Cu/Zn-SOD) and POD (POD1, POD2 and POD3) isozyme activities disturbance. Mercaptopropanoic acid coated QDs (CdSe/ZnS) localized in Medicago sativa cytoplasm and nucleus and generate ROS in a dose-dependent manner (Santos et al., 2010). Photoactive ENPs upon exposure to sunlight produces ROS through photocatalyzed dissolution process and enhanced the toxicity of these ENPs to organisms. For instance, TiO2 and ZnO ENPs through photosensitization process generate reactive singlet state oxygen (1O2) intermediate in the aerial parts of plants upon exposure to sunlight. The produced 1O2 localized in the cell thylakoid membranes and this is the main reactive oxygen intermediate involved cytotoxicity in the leaves (Li, Zhang, Niu, & Chen, 2012; Triantaphylid es & Havaux, 2009). From the studies, it is clear that the activation of antioxidative machinery to detoxify the produced ROS vary with the ENPs type, plant species and exposure conditions (Table 2). Moreover, at low exposure concentrations of ENPs antioxidants effectively scavenged the generated reactive oxygen intermediates by maintaining equilibrium between ROS production and detoxification. However, in the scenario of higher ENPs concentrations, plants antioxidant defense system fails to protect the cellular organelles from oxidative damages. Non-enzymatic antioxidants such as ascorbate, proline, tocopherols, plastoquinones, vitamin B6, flavonoids, thiols, carotenoids, and phenolics are also involved in the quenching of reactive oxygen intermediates produced in different plants species under stress conditions (Li et al., 2012; Triantaphylid es & Havaux, 2009). Ascorbate is an important antioxidant involved in the scavenging of superoxide and hydroxyl reactive intermediates and can also convert tocopheroxyl radical into a-tocopherol to prevent the direct membrane damage (Li et al., 2012). Shaw and Hossain (2013) have reported the consistent increase in ascorbate level in the leaves of rice seedlings to quench the produced H2O2 in the response of CuO ENPs. The activity of phenylalanine ammonia lyase (PAL), a key enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of anthocyanin (a flavonoid), increased 10-fold in Arabidopsis thaliana upon exposure to 1000mg L 1 CeO2 ENPs as compared to control (Ma et al., 2016). The level of proline content elevated 2 times in rice (Oryza sativa L.) seedlings in the response of Ag ENPs (1mg L 1) which act as a ROS quencher (Nair & Chung, 2014a). The carotenoids content in plant leaves, which is another non-enzymatic antioxidant, decreased upon cellular uptake of copper and silver nano-particles (Nair & Chung, 2014a; Shaw & Hossain, 2013). Phenolics are another group of compounds which play the role as an antioxidant by quenching free
radicals, donating electrons or chelating metal ions. Foliar application of Cu(OH)2 nano-pesticides at the concentration of 100mg per plant to maize considerably enhanced ( 24–122%) the biosynthesis of phenolic acid precursors (phenylalanine and 4-hydroxyphenylalanine), p-Coumaric acid and total phenolic contents (Zhao, Hu, Huang, & Keller, 2017). Moreover, the role of above mentioned non-enzymatic antioxidants in the response of ENPs induced oxidative stress to plants is not clear. Therefore further in-depth investigations are required to understand the mechanism of nanotoxicity in plants and defense response of different enzymatic and nonenzymatic antioxidants.

sections.heading: 3.4. Geno-toxic effects at the molecular level
sections.text:
In recent years, the role of ENPs as a potential mutagenic agent is gaining attention upon interaction with plant cells. ENPs induced geno-toxicity mainly through chromosomal aberration, micronuclei induction, disturbing cell cycle as well as alteration of genes expression and protein synthesis involved in the growth regulation, metabolism and biotic or abiotic stress response (Kaveh et al., 2013; Pakrashi, Jain, et al., 2014; Wang et al., 2017). The transcriptomic analysis provides important information about the mechanism of ENPs induced genotoxicity through the up and downregulation of genes. In this regard, Arabidopsis thaliana is considered a model plant system for geno-toxic studies due to its smaller genome comparative to other plants. In Arabidopsis thaliana transcriptions of 286 genes were up-regulated and 81 genes were down-regulated after treatment of 5mg L 1 polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP)-coated Ag ENPs. Primarily upregulated genes were associated with plant defense system (mainly thalianol biosynthesis pathway) in the response of abiotic (metal) and oxidative stress. Whereas, down-regulated genes were related to plants response to pathogens and hormones stimuli (auxin-regulated gene) (Kaveh et al., 2013). In another study environmentally relevant concentration of Ag ENPs (1mg L 1) up-regulated the expression levels of sulfur assimilation and glutathione (GSH) biosynthesis genes in Arabidopsis thaliana (Nair & Chung, 2014b). Moreover, CeO2 and In2O5 ENPs differentially modulated the expression of iron-regulating genes (ferric-chelate-reductase, Fe-regulated transporter, and ferritin) in wild-type A. thaliana. The application of real-time polymerase chain reaction (Real-Time PCR) or quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) in nano-phyto-toxicity studies has made possible to understand the molecular basis of geno-toxicity. In cucumber (Cucumis sativus) and wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) plants, silver sulfide ENPs exposure at 10mg L 1 concentration altered the expression of genes involved in ethylene signaling pathway, miraculin-like proteins
(MLPs) and aquaporins. These up and down-regulated genes normally play role in plant development, water transport, defense against bacteria and other pathogens invasion as well as other cellular processes (Wang et al., 2017). Plants (rice, maize) antioxidant defense machinery genes (APX, CAT, FSD, GST1, MSD, POD1) transcription up-regulated in response of CuO (50mg L 1) and Ag (0.5mg L 1) ENPs (Nair & Chung, 2014a; Zhao, Hu, et al., 2017). Metallothionein (MT), a cysteine-rich metal-binding protein, de novo expressed MT gene in wheat roots upon sand born exposure of 2.5mg kg 1 Ag ENPs (Dimkpa, McLean, et al., 2013). TiO2 ENPs up-regulated the expression profile of 11 micro-RNAs in tobacco. These microRNAs are the class of recently discovered small non-coding RNA, play role in plant development, genes modulation, and tolerance against environmental stresses (Frazier, Burklew, & Zhang, 2014). Comet assay is a widely used technique to assess the damage in DNA structure. Even low exposure concentration of TiO2 ENPs (12.5mg L 1) reduced the mitotic index and induced the chromosomal aberration in the onion roots (Allium cepa L.). Microscopic techniques along with comet assay confirmed the chromosome breakage, micronuclei formation, sticky and multipolar chromosomes (Pakrashi, Jain, et al., 2014). In addition of comet assay, DNA laddering assay can be used to investigate the DNA internucleosomal cleavage and plants apoptotic cell death upon interaction with CNTs (Ghosh, Bhadra, Adegoke, Bandyopadhyay, & Mukherjee, 2015). These studies indicate that ENPs upon interaction with plants induced cyto-genotoxic effects and regulate the expression levels of different genes involved in physiological and biochemical processes (Table 2). However, further in-depth studies are required in order to understand the severity of DNA damage, mechanism of plants recovery from DNA damage, and intergenerational transfer of traits to next progeny under the influence of nano-genotoxicity. Moreover, proteomic, and metabolomic studies should also be conducted to understand the complex ENPs interaction with different plant species.

sections.heading: 4. Effects and bioaccumulation of ENPs in multicellular aquatic and terrestrial organisms
sections.text:
ENMs ever-increasing production and use across wide-ranging sectors releasing a substantial quantities of ENPs (intentionally or unintentionally) into the environment either from the point or non-point sources (Vance et al., 2015). The free dispersible ENPs are produced and used in large quantities and inevitably release into different aquatic environmental systems during production process, use phase, discharge, disposal, recycling, runoff and/or atmospheric deposition. Principally discharge of untreated or
partially treated wastewater from ENMs production units into water bodies is the potential source of indirect environmental contamination with ENPs (Holden et al., 2014). According to an estimate, 0.1–2% ENPs during the production process is released into the atmosphere, water and soil system (Keller, McFerran, Lazareva, & Suh, 2013). The wastewater effluents are the point source for ENPs; and the discharge of the upstream wastewater treatment plant highly affect the water quality of the downstream drinking water treatment (Zhang et al., 2019). In recent years, a number of ENPs ecotoxicity studies have been conducted using different multicellular organisms inhabiting in aquatic and terrestrial environments (Connolly et al., 2016; Sonane, Moin, & Satish, 2017). Toxic effects of various ENPs to multicellular aquatic and terrestrial organisms are presented in Table 3. An organism’s habitat plays a vital role in determining the ENPs exposure route to the organism. For instance, inhalation or ingestion is the primary intake pathway for the terrestrial organisms, whereas in aquatic organisms, ENPs uptake occurs normally through feeding, dermal absorption and/or gills. In case of gastrointestinal intake with the consumption of ENPs contaminated food, these ENPs are either excreted out or redistributed to other body organs (Lin, Tian, Wu, & Xing, 2010). In the comparison of soil and sediment-dwelling organisms, ENPs are more bioavailable to aquatic biota, where in former case ENPs binding with minerals hinder absorption in organisms. Generally, ENPs interaction with an organism occurs through adsorption on the cell surface, cell membrane internalization, ions release with ENPs dissolution and mechanistic nano-bio-effects (Baker, Tyler, & Galloway, 2014). CNTs primarily interact with epithelial surfaces and induce toxicity without absorption across epithelial membranes (Petersen et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 4.1. Cellular uptake and nano-toxicity mechanism
sections.text:
The cellular uptake mechanisms of ENPs across plasma membrane involved passive transport (diffusion or perisorption), endocytosis and non-endocytosis pathways. Diffusion is the dominant trafficking process across membranes for small (<5nm), positively charged and hydrophobic ENPs (Baker et al., 2014). The cellular uptake pathway and mechanism of nano toxicity in multicellular organisms is shown in Figure 4. Perisorption of smaller, positively charged particles may occur through intestine microvilli/villi, enterocyte cells in paracellular-tight junction channels and enterocyte protrusion gaps (Cornelis et al., 2014). Primarily intact ENPs enter the tissues through endocytosis pathway and respiratory or digestive systems epithelial tissue lines are the potential sites for this uptake process. Receptor-mediated endocytosis (RME), also known as clathrin-mediated endocytosis directed the ENPs toward the

organism lysosome. This endocytosis pathway may cause the intracellular toxicity due to the high content of labile metal ions through a process called “Trojan horse” effect. Other endocytosis pathways including caveolae/lipid raft-dependent endocytosis and macropinocytosis did not transport the ENPs for lysosomal degradation, but inside cell, particles remain in nano-form (Tangaa et al., 2016). Ions released as a result of ENPs dissolution are internalized in the cell through transporter proteins or ion channels. For instance, Na ion channels are involved in the uptake of ionic Ag in freshwater fish rainbow trout (Bury & Wood, 1999). As ENPs have the tendency to bind with protein (protein-corona) and aggregate in saline solution so these are not excreted out of an organism’s body like regular contaminants via excretory organs (Lin et al., 2010). So, once ENPs has entered the cell, these localized in different subcellular compartments and alter the cytophysiology. Primary ENPs toxicity induction modes include but not limited to the release of ions with particles dissolution, oxidative stress, cellular protein injury, membrane and DNA damage (Das et al., 2018; Sonane et al., 2017; Zhao, He, Lu, & Duo, 2017). In the heterogonous system, ENPs physico-chemical characteristics such as shape, size, charge, crystalline phase, coating materials could influence their bioactivity and toxicity. Oral exposure of TiO2 ENPs to mice caused the oxidative stress, chromosomal aberrations and adversely affected the liver function with increasing exposure concentration from 50 to 500mg kg 1 (Ali et al., 2019). For cellular trafficking particles have to pass through the cell membrane pores, thus the ENPs transport is directly dependent on particle size. Smaller size (10 nm) CuO ENPs induces more toxicity to sea urchin (Lytechinus pictus) embryos with low EC50/96 h (450 ppb) comparative to the larger size particles (50 nm) (EC50 ¼ 5395 ppb). This is might be
Figure 4. Cellular uptake of ENPs through the cell membrane and mechanisms of cell damage. Adapted from Qu et al. (2013) and Sukhanova et al. (2018).
due to the higher dissolution of small size embryo internalized particles (Torres-Duarte et al., 2016). Ag ENPs exposure to terrestrial isopods (Porcellio scaber) in concentration range of 0.28 to 36mg mL 1 through feeding hazelnut leaves for 14 days caused changes in proteins, lipids, nucleic acids and carbohydrates (Novak et al., 2019). Particles morphology also mediates the nano-toxicity to the organisms. Exposure of rod-shaped Fe2O3 ENPs in concentration range of 25–100 lg mL
1 effectively accumulate in the cell line of Madin-Darby Canine Kidney (MDCK) and produces more cytotoxicity with greater oxidative and membrane damage than sphere shape particles (Cardillo et al., 2016). When fibroblast of Tursiops truncates exposed to different concentrations (20, 50, 100, 150 lg mL 1) of anatase and rutile TiO2 ENPs, rutile form substantially break DNA strand and caused the genotoxic effect with oxidative stress (Frenzilli et al., 2014). Positively charged CeO2 ENPs is more toxic and bio-accumulated to a greater degree than negative or neutral particles due to membranes surface negative potential (Collin, Oostveen, Tsyusko, & Unrine, 2014). Moreover, after internalization in cell positively charged ENPs has the affinity to bind with proteins, vitamins or other ion and localized in lysosome which trigger CeO2 (þ) oxidase activity due to acidic microenvironment (Collin et al., 2014). Dietary exposure of poly(allylamine hydrochloride) functionalized positively charged Au ENPs (4 nm) at 1–50lg L 1 concentration to planktonic crustacean Daphnia magna induces cellular stress through upregulation of glutathione S-transferase (GST), heat shock protein 70 (Hsp70), and metallothionein1 (MT1) genes (Dominguez et al., 2015). In terrestrial isopod Porcellio scaber, the dietary exposure of 2000, or 5000mg g 1 of CeO2 ENPs for 14 days decreased the feeding rate and increased the lipid peroxidation level (Malev et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 4.2. Environmental conditions and co-existing effects of contaminants on nano-toxicity
sections.text:
Photoactive ENPs such as Ti and Zn upon exposure to sunlight generate ROS through photo-catalyzed dissolution and disproportionally enhanced the toxicity to organisms. In photo-dissolution process residual photogenerated holes on ZnO surfaces could attack the Zn-O bond and disassociate Zn2þ from ZnO surface. Photo-dissolution of ZnO ENPs has been expressed in the following reactions (Han, Qiu, & Gao, 2010),
ZnOðsÞ þ hv ! ZnOðsÞ þ hþ þ e ðphoto catalysisÞ (4) hþ þ e ! hvðor heatÞðre combinationÞ (5)
ZnOðsÞ þ 2hþ ! Znðaq:Þ2þ þ 1=2O2ðnano zinc oxide photo dissolutionÞ

Whereas,ZnO(s) ¼ solid ZnOhv¼ photon reaching at solid ZnO surfacehþ ¼ photogenerated hole at ZnO surfacee ¼ photogenerated electron on ZnO surfaceZn(aq.)
2þ ¼ Zn in ionic form dissolved from ZnO Photo induced cytotoxicity of ZnO ENPs through loss in viability, membrane damage and ROS generation was observed even at <1mg L 1 exposure concentrations to fresh water algae Scenedesmus obliquus (Bhuvaneshwari et al., 2015). TiO2 ENPs exposure to Zebrafish (Danio rerio) during the developmental stage at an environmentally relevant concentration (1 ng mL 1) for a period of 23 days and illumination with artificial light in the range of solar spectrum caused impaired growth, malformations, slow metamorphosis, and genotoxic effects. The oxidative damage with irradiation is confirmed with the elevated level of 8-hydroxy20-deoxyguanosine DNA adducts (Bar-Ilan et al., 2013). Environmental conditions, like natural organic matter (NOM), ionic strength (IS), pH, and background electrolyte composition, temperature, light, contact time between ENPs and natural colloids, synergistic/antagonistic interaction between NPs influences nano-toxicity of ENPs (Peng, Zhang, et al., 2017). Meanwhile, in natural waters there are much higher concentrations of suspended sediments (e.g., clay particles) that heteroaggregate rapidly with the ENPs, removing them from the water column fairly rapidly. Furthermore, a number of organic and inorganic contaminants are distributed in the natural environment. ENPs act as a carrier to transport these environmental contaminants into the cells of living organisms due to their tremendous sorption capacity. These ENPs surface adsorb contaminants have synergistic or antagonistic effects on the toxicity of ENPs to different organisms depending on the contaminant surface charge and ENPs zeta potential (Deng, Lin, et al., 2017). The co-exposure of arsenic (50 lg L 1) with TiO2 ENPs (1mg L
1) to estuarine polychaete Laeonereis acuta at nominal concentration increased the ROS level and glutathione reductase (GR) activity, reduce the antioxidant capacity as well as vandalized the organism lipid and DNA damage (Nunes et al., 2017). Moreover, the synergistic effect of co-exposure influences the metabolization capacity of estuarine polychaete and accumulates the moderately toxic dimethylated arsenic forms in the organism. In blue mussel Mytilus edulis the simultaneous absorption of TiO2 ENPs with carcinogenic polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) benzo[a]pyrene (B[a]P) from seawater induced the chromosomal aberration and oxidative damage. TiO2 ENPs may act as an activator and break-down the (B[a]P) into more reactive products inside the cells (Farkas et al., 2015). Potentially toxic elements
(PTEs) Cd and Zn assimilated in the freshwater zooplankton Daphnia magna and the levels of metallothioneins (MTs) and ROS are affected due to the strong binding of ionic metals with the TiO2 ENPs in the gut (Tan & Wang, 2014). In the heterogeneous environment ENPs ecotoxicity monitoring is a challenging task. In aquatic and terrestrial ecosystem certain multicellular organisms are serving as bio-indicators to monitor the environmental toxicology of ENPs. Earthworms (Eisenia Andrei, Eisenia fetida) are ecologically relevant receptors and their primary response in ENPs contaminated soil is habitat avoidance which minimizes the deleterious effects on their survival, growth, cocoon production and viability (Liang et al., 2017; McShane, Sarrazin, Whalen, Hendershot, & Sunahara, 2012). Caenorhabditis elegans is a soil-dwelling nematode used as a model organism to test the ENPs toxicity and bioaccumulation. Caenorhabditis elegans responds to the lethal effects of TiO2, SiO2, and ZnO ENPs at environmentally relevant concentrations by producing ROS and changing locomotion behavior, growth and reproduction (Wu et al., 2013). Multiple toxicity biomarkers such as behavioral impairment (burrowing kinetics, feeding rate, swimming behavior) and modification in biochemical response including lysozyme synthesis, oxyradical, and nitric oxide (NO.) production, and inflammatory response with the activation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinases (p38 MAPK) were detected in zebrafish Danio rerio, polychaete Hediste diversicolor and bivalves mollusks upon ENPs intracellular localization (Buffet et al., 2011; Canesi et al., 2010; Skjolding et al., 2017). These studies indicate the ENPs potential ecological risks toward the organism energy acquisition, viability, growth, development, and reproduction, which in turn influence the ecological relationship and the sustainability of an ecosystem.

sections.heading: 4.3. ENPs trophic level transfer and impacts on mammals
sections.text:
Moreover, after intact ENPs tissue internalization in lower trophic level organisms, body surfaces adsorption, bio-accumulation in the gut lumen and subsequent transfer of ENPs from prey to predator is a novel scenario (Tangaa et al., 2016). Bio-accumulation and bio-magnification of ENPs in food chain members through trophic level transfer is possible in addition to direct exposure (Luo et al., 2016). Thus, its utmost important to determine nano-toxicity in organisms lying at different levels of the food web. In hornworms, three different size Au ENPs were transferred with food through the consumption of ENPs contaminated tobacco leaves. The biomagnification process was found to be dependent on the particles zeta potential rather than particles size (Judy, Unrine, & Bertsch, 2011). Daphnia magna is a well-known primary consumer for food chain eco-
toxicity study in aquatic ecosystem and natural prey of many other organisms. Au ENPs bio-accumulated in Daphnia magna when fed with contaminated algae (Lee et al., 2015). ENPs transferred from Daphnia magna to zebrafish (Danio rerio) and 10 folds more body burden was recorded upon dietary uptake in comparison of water born exposure (Skjolding, WintherNielsen, & Baun, 2014). Recently, Dong, Xia, Yang, Lin, and Mao (2018) has confirmed the trophic level transfer of 14C-labeled graphene from bacteria (Escherichia coli) to vertebrate (Danio rerio) in aquatic food chain via protozoa (Tetrahymena thermophile) and zooplankton (Daphnia magna). Through the trophic level transfer of ENPs, different sub-lethal effects including changes in growth and development, lifespan reduction and impaired reproduction have been reported (Luo et al., 2016; Tangaa et al., 2016). Bio-magnification through the food chain is considered to be dependent on both abiotic (ENPs properties, exposure condition of prey) and biotic factors (physiology of organisms, predator-prey relationship, food web structure, analyzed organ) (Judy et al., 2011; Luo et al., 2016). Mammals including human-beings are the ultimate recipient of the ENPs distributed in different compartments of the environment either through dermal absorption, inhalation or ingestion with the consumption of contaminated food. A summary of different carbon-based, metal and metal oxide ENPs toxicological effects to mammals is presented in Table 4. Intravenous administration of ultra-small superparamagnetic-Fe3O4 (0.4, 2 and 10lg kg 1) and diesel exhaust (400 lg kg 1) ENPs to mice increased the levels of oxidative stress-related biomarkers (lipid peroxidation, ROS, SOD) and induced DNA damage (Nemmar et al., 2015). The author speculated that small size particles specifically responsible for biological response due to their deep cellular penetration capacity. When mice were exposed to ultrafine Cu (15.7 nm) atmosphere containing 3.5mg m 3 Cu ENPs, these ENPs were redistributed in the animal body. These ENPs caused pulmonary inflammation with increased activity of neutrophils and different cytokines/chemokines. Moreover, the expression levels of several immune responsive genes including Th1/Th2 were also altered in the spleen of Cu ENPs treated mice as compared to the control (Adamcakova-Dodd, Monick, Powers, Gibson-Corley, & Thorne, 2015). Co-exposure of ENPs can either have additive or antagonistic effects on the organisms. Tsugita, Morimoto, and Nakayama (2017) have observed the drastic lung inflammation in C57BL/6 N female mice with caspase-1 inflammasome activation and secretion of interleukin-1b (IL-1b) cytokine under the synergistic influence of widely used TiO2 and SiO2 ENPs. In order to study the genotoxic and mutagenic effects of ENPs, Åkerlund et al. (2018) have treated the human bronchial epithelial cell line (HBECL) and mouse embryonic stem cell line (MECL) with Ni ENPs, NiO and soluble Ni chloride. Hypoxanthine
