Moreover, Al2O3 ENPs triggered up-regulation of genes associated with cell cycle retardation at the G2/ S stage and ultimately cell death in human lung adenocarcinoma cell line (A549) (Li, Zhang, et al., 2016). Omics approach also detected the perturbations in normal cellular functioning in the response to alumina ENPs (Li, Zhang, et al., 2016). Carbon black ENPs induced neurotoxicity in the mice offsprings through the over-expression of the glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and aquaporin-4 after maternal exposure to ENPs in dose-dependent manner (Onoda, Takeda, & Umezawa, 2017).

sections.heading: 5. Removal and degradation strategies of ENPs in the environment
sections.text:
Nanotechnology-based consumer products are the inescapable part of everyday life in this millennium. In addition to providing enormous benefits, these nano-enabled products generated a new category of waste called nano-waste which is toxic to the humans and other organisms in the environment. Conventional methods of waste handling and treatment are not sufficient for the disposal of nano-wastes (Bystrzejewska-Piotrowska et al., 2009). For the purpose of efficient nano-waste handling, the categorization of nano-waste as a function of constituent material toxicity and exposure potency provide several benefits including effective waste treatment and disposal to mitigate the ENPs eco-toxicity hazardous (Bakiu, 2018). Different physical, chemical, and biological methods are used for the treatment of waste containing ENPs. However, no single technique can remove emerging nano-scale environmental pollutants from the waste streams with 100% efficiency. Moreover, the bio-solid produced after nano-waste treatment is either applied directly to agricultural fields as fertilizers or deposited in landfills in the form of slag/fly ash after incineration of solid waste. For instance, only in the USA and China 190,000 metric tons per annum of ten major nano-materials embedded in personal care products end up in landfills (Keller, Vosti, Wang, & Lazareva, 2014). Life cycle analysis of Ag and TiO2 contaminated municipal solid waste (MSW) application to the agricultural soil have indicated the toxic impact of these ENPs to the human health and terrestrial ecosystem (Stamou & Antizar-Ladislao, 2016). Although the incinerated solid waste products are considered stable, however weathering process in landfills containing incineration residues can release the ENPs counterpart fractions in the leachate that could pose a threat of groundwater contamination and unknown consequences on other environmental compartments (Mitrano, Mehrabi, Dasilva, & Nowack, 2017). Thus, it is crucial to closely monitor and regulate the ENPs
concentration in the treated effluents, solid waste and landfills leachate for ecosystem safety.

sections.heading: 5.1. Role of natural clays in removal of ENPs
sections.text:
In the natural environment variety of clay minerals presence play an important role in the removal of contaminants (Ismadji, Soetaredjo, & Ayucitra, 2015). Clay minerals have variable surface charge and geometric dimensions. The most common clay minerals are kaolinite, montmorillonite, vermiculite, mica and etc. Kaolinite is 1:1 type clay consisting of silica tetrahedral sheets connected via apical oxygen atoms to aluminum dioctahedral sheets. Montmorillonite is 2:1 type clay with sheet-like structure, in which two layers of Si-tetrahedra sandwich one layer of Al-octahedra (Liu et al., 2017). These clay minerals have tendency to adsorb various pollutants and other materials due to high cation exchange capacity (CEC), more specific surface area and swelling nature (Gupta, Dhawan, & Shanker, 2016). The interaction of clay minerals with ENPs largely determine their fate in the environment through heteroaggregation, and sedimentation. Clay particles can also coagulate the ENPs in aqueous environments and thus play role in the removal of nano-contaminants. Kaolin clay destabilizes the Ag and TiO2 ENPs in the aqueous system and promoted the sedimentation of these ENPs through heteroaggregation process (Wang et al., 2015). Electrostatic interaction of CeO2 ENPs with kaolinite change the distribution of surface charge density from homogenous to heterogeneous charged plane (Guo, Jiang, Serem, Sharma, & Ma, 2019). Zhang group (Zhang, Petersen, et al., 2012) has found that soil clay minerals (kaolinite, smectite and shale) removed the MWCNTs from the aqueous media through sorption on clay surface followed by settling of aggregated CNTs. The affinity of clay particles interaction with ENPs depends on the ENPs surface characteristics, clay/ENPs concentration ratio and solution chemistry (pH, ionic strength, NOM), in addition of type of clay mineral particles (Labille, Harns, Bottero, & Brant, 2015). Moreover, aggregation process reduces the surface area to volume thus effects the reactivity and toxicity of ENPs. The heteroaggregation of TiO2 ENPs with montmorillonite clay particles drastically reduces the toxic effect of ENPs on development of zebrafish embryos (Kansara, Kumar, & Karakoti, 2020). The hydrogen-bonding and Lewis acid-base interactions induced the aggregation of carbon dots (CDs) with soil minerals in addition to van der Waals and electrical double-layer forces and reduce the bioavailability of these carbon based ENMs (Liu et al., 2017). The presence of montmorillonite in the CuO ENPs exposure medium play a protective role in the development of zebrafish embryo by reducing the bioavailability of
ENPs (Kansara, Paruthi, Misra, Karakoti, & Kumar, 2019). Montmorillonite clay particles modulates the bioavailability and toxicity of Ag and ZnO ENPs to zebrafish (Danio rerio) and Tetrahymena pyriformis, respectively (Gupta et al., 2017, 2016). The low cost, nonhazardous, and ubiquitous presence in nature make clay minerals the most environmentally relevant sorbent for the water treatment technology. Thus, these clay particles are the potential candidate for the decontamination of engineered nanomaterials in the environment.

sections.heading: 5.2. Biogenic synthesis and role of biochar in nano-pollutants waste handling
sections.text:
Bio-genic synthesis of environment-friendly nano-materials using the principles of green chemistry has emerged a sustainable approach in a recent couple of years. Nano-materials bio-genic synthesis involved one step reduction and stabilization through biological routes relying on microbes, algae, plants or their derived products (biomolecules) using the principles of nano-bio-technology (Saratale et al., 2018). Green synthesis approach can substantially reduce the use of toxic chemicals and solvents used in the conventional energy-intensive physical and chemical fabrication processes (Singh et al., 2018). As, according to the estimates of Woodrow Wilson Center considerable amount of waste is sent to landfill sites during the entire life cycle of ENPs containing products (Bystrzejewska-Piotrowska et al., 2009). Thus, in order to overcome the emission of toxic contaminants into the natural environment and reduce human health hazards green synthesis/biogenic synthesis of ENMs with distinct properties (morphology, size, and bioactivity) is a reliable, eco-friendly and sustainable approach for a wide range of nano-materials. Biochar is a carbon-rich solid product, produced at a relatively low temperature (300–700 C) from diverse waste biomass materials during pyrolysis process and contain a variety of functional groups (Abbas et al., 2018; Liu, Liu, Yousaf, & Abbas, 2018). It can be used effectively for the remediation of environmental contaminants (Ahmad et al., 2014; Yousaf, Liu, Abbas, Ullah, et al., 2018). Recently, biochar has been applied successfully in the soil system to immobilize different ENPs by surface interaction. It reduced the bioavailability, uptake, and accumulation of CeO2, and Ag ENPs to soil fauna Oligochaeta (Enchytraeus albidus) and earthworm (Eisenia fetida) (Nyoka, Kanyile, Bredenhand, Prinsloo, & Voua Otomo, 2018; Servin et al., 2018). The possible mechanism of ENPs adsorption on biochar surface is shown in Figure 5. It has also alleviated the phyto-toxic effects of ENPs to different food crops (Abbas et al., 2020; Sima, Shen, Fang, Yu, & Jiang, 2017). In our recent study, bamboo waste derived
biochar substantially reduced the uptake and bioaccumulation of Ag ENPs in the rice plants (Abbas et al., 2019). Similarly, Rice husk (RH) derived biochar efficiently ameliorated the bio-toxicity of CuO ENPs in wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) plants by immobilizing the ENPs with space shield effect and surface adsorption of released Cu2þ ions (Sima et al., 2017). Biochar surface functionalities such as carboxyl (-COOH), hydroxyl (-OH) and aromatic groups are responsible for overcoming repulsive forces between ENPs and biochar (Abbas et al., 2020). In our recent study, we have found that biochar reduced the bioaccumulation of CeO2 ENPs in wheat plants through its surface functionalities mainly carboxylate and hydroxyl functional groups (Abbas et al., 2020). Hydrogen bonding in addition of charge transfer and van der Waals interaction likely the predominant driving forces involved in the irreversible heteroaggregation of ENP contaminants with biochar (Uchimiya, Pignatello, White, Hu, & Ferreira, 2017). The stable complex formation capability of biochar can immobilize and retain remarkably high (>22mg g 1) concentration of Au ENPs on its surface (Uchimiya et al., 2017). Other mechanisms of nano-pollutants bioavailability reduction through biochar addition involved the alternation in the pH of exposure medium which reduced the dissolution process of ENPs (Abbas et al., 2019). Thus, from the above studies, it is clear that biochar can be used as an effective in situ remedial agent in the nano-waste contaminated soil to prevent the food chain accumulation and dietary human exposure of ENPs.
Figure 5. Mechanism of ENPs interaction and adsorption on biochar surface.

sections.heading: 5.3. Bioremediation approach for sustainable environment
sections.text:
Bioremediation is regarded a safe and economical method for the removal of contaminants from the environment utilizing microbes and plants based system (Abhilash, Powell, Singh, & Singh, 2012). Microbes degrade the ENPs in the environment especially carbon-based nano-materials with the secretion of extracellular enzymes and EPS (Schreiner et al., 2009; Zhang, Chen, & Alvarez, 2014). Biodegradation of the ENPs surface coating or core component is possible. This is particularly relevant for the carbonbased ENMs including CNTs and fullerene. For instance, white-rot basidiomycete fungi can enzymatically degrade the hydroxylated fullerol (C60 (OH)19-27) by the oxidation process and mineralized it to CO2 in 32weeks (Schreiner et al., 2009). In a recent study, Zhang and coworkers (Zhang et al., 2014) have observed the degradation of close cage SWCNT structure either by the direct Mn3þ oxidation process or through the malonate mediated pathway with a naturally occurring extracellular enzyme manganese peroxidase (MnP). Horseradish-peroxidase (HRP) is another phyto-enzyme existing in the rhizospheric zone of horseradish has been successfully applied for the biological degradation of carboxylated and nitrogen-doped MWCNTs (Zhao, Allen, & Star, 2011). Heme-active HRP interacts with nanotubes oxygen functional defective sites by hydrophilic interaction and promoted the oxidative layer by layer degradation of nanotubes due to their multilayer graphitic structure. During the degradation process of carbon-based nanomaterials, the length and diameter of materials reduced, carboxyl groups are added, and CO2 is produced (Schreiner et al., 2009; Zhang et al., 2014). More recently, Mukherjee et al. (Mukherjee et al., 2018) has investigated the bio-degradation of graphene oxide (GO) with neutrophil myeloperoxidase (MPO), a peroxidase enzyme generated in humans, and resulting graphene degraded product is non-cytotoxic for human lungs. These findings elucidate the carbon-based materials degradation potential of various enzymes secreted by different organisms and thereby diminishing the environmental hazards to diverse ecologicalcommunities. For all types of ENPs, organic surface coating bio-degradation is relevant, as these surface coatings are applied to improve the ENPs stability for their various applications. A large number of organic polymers are currently used as a matrix material for the surface coating of ENPs to obtain the desired properties (Al-Kattan et al., 2014; Rhiem et al., 2016; Vorbau, Hillemann, & Stintz, 2009). Microbial mediated degradation processes enhance the biodegradability of these polymer coatings (Bai, Wang, Abuduaini, Zhu, & Zhao, 2016; Peixoto, Silva, & Kr€uger, 2017). ENPs surface coating biological degradation induces aggregation and deposition
process. In a case study, polyethylene oxide (PEO) ENPs surface coating has been degraded by bacteria that stabilize the ENPs (Kirschling et al., 2011). Moreover, plant-microbe interaction in the rhizosphere zone (phytostimulation or rhizo-degradation) plays an important role in the plantbased (phyto-remediation) remediation system by promoting plant growth, affecting pollutants bioavailability and uptake as well as degradation, sequestration, and bio-transformation process of the ENPs (Abhilash et al., 2012). Plant-based bio-remediation approach (phyto-remediation/phytoextraction/phyto-accumulation) involved the cultivation of green plants to remove the ENPs environmental pollutants present in water, air, or soil and accumulate them in different tissues. Several terrestrial and wetland plants including Arabidopsis thaliana, duckweed species, barley (Hordeum vulgare L.), mesquite (Prosopis juliflora), mustard (Brassica juncea), alfalfa (Medicago sativa L.), water hyacinth (Eichhronia crassipes), and among others bio-accumulate metallic ENPs with either low or no negative effects on their growth and development (Gomes, da, Hauser-Davis, de Souza, & Vit oria, 2016; Rai et al., 2018). Aquatic plant duckweed species Landoltia punctate and Lemna minor can effectively bio-accumulated at least 2 fold higher concentration of Ag and Al than the environmental concentrations in both intact nano and dissolved ionic forms (Juhel et al., 2011; Stegemeier, Colman, Schwab, Wiesner, & Lowry, 2017). In natural environment, very stable ENPs such as CeO2 and TiO2 were phyto-extracted with wetland (Rumex crispus L. and Elodea canadensis) and desert Mesquite plants (Hernandez-Viezcas, Castillo-Michel, Peralta-Videa, & GardeaTorresdey, 2016; Jacob, Borchardt, Navaratnam, Otte, & Bezbaruah, 2013). Even hyper-accumulator Prosopis juliflora plant had uptake as much as 4504lg g 1 of CeO2 through roots and translocated them into aerial tissues (Hernandez-Viezcas et al., 2016). Furthermore, ENPs present in atmospheric particulate matter enter into plants through aerial portions especially leaves providing another option of phyto-remediation for the removal of these pollutants from the atmospheric environment (Gomes et al., 2016). The plants defense mechanism in response of ENPs accumulation has already been described in the section 3.3. Once contaminants are removed from the environment through phytoremediation process using hyper-accumulator plants, a lot of contaminated biomass is produced which needs to be handled in accordance with regulatory guidelines of USEPA to avoid the potential ecological risks (US-EPA, 2000). Existing conventional disposal methods of hyper-accumulated plants such as combustion, composting, incineration and landfilling, introduces secondary pollutants in the environmental compartments (air, soil and water bodies) (Rai et al., 2018). Conceptual model though cradle-to-cradle
system for handling of nano-waste is presented in Figure 6. Thus it is crucial to find sustainable alternative ways for the disposal of these pollutant hyper-accumulated plants. In this regard, the coupling of phytoremediation with bioenergy generation is a clean, economical and environment friendly option for the management of the contaminants (metallic-nano-size materials) loaded plants (Yousaf, Liu, Abbas, Ali, et al., 2018). Thermochemical conversion of metal loaded waste biomass is a promising technique to obtain multifunctional value-added products in addition to renewable and carbon-neutral energy. For the recovery of bioenergy and metal elements from the metal contaminated paper mulberry (Broussonetia papyrifera) biomass, adsorption pyrolysis is an efficient technology (Han et al., 2018). Precious metals such as Au, Pd have also been recovered through phyto-extraction followed by thermal treatment of biomass waste. Pyrolysis treatment of the ENPs containing willows and miscanthus biomass can improve the catalytic activity of these materials comparable to the commercially available catalyst (Harumain et al., 2017). Moreover, the metal loaded plants can also be a natural source of facile metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and find applications in energy storage devices (Salunkhe, Kaneti, & Yamauchi, 2017). Bioethanol a potential candidate to replace fossil fuels can be produced through green technology from the metal hyper-accumulator sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) plant biomass after enzymatic saccharification process (Dhiman et al., 2017).
Figure 6. Conceptual model though cradle-to-cradle system.
Gasification of potentially toxic metallic elements (PTMEs) Cd, Pb and Zn hyper-accumulator Sedum alfredii has indicated its potential to generate energy from biomass waste and metal stabilized biochars (Cui et al., 2018). These PTME stabilized solid biochar can be effectively reutilized for the adsorption of organic pollutants from the environmental waste streams. For instance, Gong et al. (2018) has performed the pyrolysis of Ramie (Boehmeria nivea) after phytoremediation of PTMEs contaminated sediments and obtained metal stabilized biochar adsorbed as much as 259.27mg g 1 of methylene blue from the wastewater.

sections.heading: 5.4. Legislative measures for handling ENPs
sections.text: Besides, above-mentioned strategies for the management of nano-wastes, legislative measures should be adopted to control widespread use and disposal of ENPs into the environment. In most of the countries, the current legislative framework is not sufficient to deal with the ENMs labeled products potential ecological risks during the life cycle of these products from raw material manufacturing to disposal phase (Patil, Shedbalkar, Truskewycz, Chopade, & Ball, 2016). Recently US-EPA urged to obtain more detail information about production volume, chemical density, production method, processing, possible use, environmental input and safety data under information gathering rule “toxic substances control act” from the manufacturer prior to nano-enabled products synthesis (Younis et al., 2018). Other institutions such as Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), International Waste Working Group (IWWG) on ENMs waste and European Union (EU) in collaboration with European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) are also actively involved to regularize and update the eco-toxicity test guidelines for nano-materials to prevent their environmental damage. A multifaceted approach should be adopted including advanced research, public awareness, integrated legislation, and technical assistance in periodical evaluation of nano-enabled products to obtain the maximum desirable benefits and keep the detrimental outcomes below the threshold level with the use of these products (Patil et al., 2016; Younis et al., 2018).

sections.heading: 6. Summary and future outlook
sections.text:
During the last couple of years, advancement in nanotechnology has facilitated the incorporation of novel ENPs in almost every commercial product to obtain socioeconomic benefits. Thus, the ever-increasing use of nanoenabled products releasing substantial quantities of ENPs during product lifecycle into the different compartments of the environment. ENPs
exposure to different organisms have deleterious effects on the growth and survival. Photoactive ENPs (ZnO and TiO2) upon exposure to light are toxic to organisms even at <1mg L 1 concentration. Degradation process of CdS QDs releases Cd which is toxic to sediment dwelling organisms at 0.01mg of Cd L 1. Oxidative stress through excessive production of ROS is the primary mechanism of nano-toxicity in microbes and multicellular organisms including mammals (humans). In most cases but not always ENPs interaction with plants had low concentration stimulatory and high concentration inhibitory impacts. ENPs caused phyto-toxicity at physiological and morphological levels by modifying various biochemical pathways. Plants also respond to ENPs through up and down-regulation of several genes involved in different cellular functioning. Conclusively, the toxicity of ENPs to various organism depends on the exposure concentration, method of exposure, organism growth stage and habitat as well as environmental conditions. The management of nano-waste is utmost important as according to global estimates up-to 90% of the ENPs contained in nano-products ultimately end up in landfills or sewage sludge. In most of the countries especially in developing ones, the dumping of nanowaste at open landfill sits or application to agricultural lands makes the scenario worse. Thus, it is crucial to adopt certain sustainable approaches for the synthesis of nano-enables products and eco-friendly handling of nano-waste. Phytoremediation of nano-waste contaminated sites followed by thermochemical conversion of plants biomass into various usable products such as renewable energy source and stabilized green synthesis material for various potential applications is a good option. In order to avoid the irreversible consequences of ENPs on the ecosystem functioning and human health, future studies should address the following challenges.
1. There is a strong need to develop standard protocols to test the nanoecotoxicity at environmentally relevant concentration of ENPs with chronic exposure. As most of the nano-toxicity studies are performed at much higher concentration than the ENPs predicted environment concentration without out considering their dynamic transformation processes and interaction with other components of the ecosystem. 2. In addition to conventional toxicity biomarkers commonly used for other contaminants, omics-based techniques such as genomics, metabolomics, proteomics, and transcriptomics should be applied to understand the molecular basis of nano-toxicology. 3. Studies about the tropical transfer of ENPs and bio-magnification through the consumption of contaminated food in the aquatic and terrestrial food web are areas of concern.
4. Explore the co-exposure behavior of ENPs with other contaminants in the environmental matrices as these caused “Trojan horse” effect by accelerating ENPs bioaccumulation through alteration in bioavailability and uptake to different organisms. 5. For a better understanding of nano-phytotoxicity, the relationship between genes expression and signaling transduction pathways of ROS in the response of ENPs should be studied in addition to potential trans-generational effects. Moreover, plants enzymatic and non-enzymatic anti-oxidant defense system to cope with the nano-toxicity need consideration. 6. Green synthesis of ENPs incorporated products according to the outlines of US-EPA is a promising field for researchers to synthesis environmental benign materials. 7. Development of safety paradigm and legislative framework for the efficient management of nano-waste particularly newly developed nanoenabled products for environment health safety (EHS). 8. Seek feasible and environmentally safe methods to recycle and deactivate the ENPs in nano-waste. For this purpose, efficient bioremediation of nano-waste contaminated sites and enhanced bioaccumulation of ENPs, transgenic organisms should be explored to successfully integrate the bio-remediation with renewable energy generation and nanowaste recycling.
In conclusion, experts from all relevant fields should collaborate to develop eco-friendly sustainable nanotechnology-based products to obtain maximal benefits with minimal ecological hazards.

referenceMentions.context: To cite this article: Qumber Abbas, Balal Yousaf, Habib Ullah, Muhammad Ubaid Ali, Yong Sik Ok & Jörg Rinklebe (2020): Environmental transformation and nano-toxicity of engineered nanoparticles (ENPs) in aquatic and terrestrial organisms, Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology, DOI: 10.

The carbon based nanomaterials such as graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) has tendency to combine with the different gases and water vapors and change which change their reactivity (Yu et al., 2015).

These are crucial for normal ecosystem functioning as these perform variety of ecosystem services such as nutrient cycling, organic matter (OM) decomposition and degradation of toxic pollutants (Ren et al., 2018; Soliveres et al., 2016).
Most commonly used bacteria for nano-toxicity studies belong to genus Bacillus, Pseudomonas (Doody, Wang, Bais, & Jin, 2016; Fajardo et al., 2014), Escherichia (Kaweeteerawat et al.

The degradation of such ENPs incorporated products with time release the product nanoparticles in the environment which upon interaction with bacteria affect their growth, development and other ecosystem services (Fajardo et al., 2014; Soliveres et al., 2016).

The degradation of such ENPs incorporated products with time release the product nanoparticles in the environment which upon interaction with bacteria affect their growth, development and other ecosystem services (Fajardo et al., 2014; Soliveres et al., 2016).

Generally inside the cell toxicity is induced with the trigger of oxidative stress, that is the production of free radicals mainly ROS, protein deactivation and gene expression alteration (Fajardo et al., 2014; Kaweeteerawat et al., 2015).

Studies have shown the impact of ENPs on fungi is linked with the cell membrane damage, inhibition of growth, reduced cell density, cytoplasm blebbing, cell death and eventually loss in decomposition activity with reduction in lignocellulolytic enzymes production (Han et al., 2012; Shah et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2018).
mercaptopropanoic acid QDs (CdSe/ZnS) particles (4–6 nm) localized inside the nucleus and cytoplasmic regions (Santos et al., 2010).
Mesoporous silica nano-particles (MSPs) localized in the cell chloroplast after cellular internalization (Sun et al., 2014).
Mercaptopropanoic acid coated QDs (CdSe/ZnS) localized in Medicago sativa cytoplasm and nucleus and generate ROS in a dose-dependent manner (Santos et al., 2010).

Non-enzymatic antioxidants such as ascorbate, proline, tocopherols, plastoquinones, vitamin B6, flavonoids, thiols, carotenoids, and phenolics are also involved in the quenching of reactive oxygen intermediates produced in different plants species under stress conditions (Li et al., 2012; Triantaphylid es & Havaux, 2009).

Ascorbate is an important antioxidant involved in the scavenging of superoxide and hydroxyl reactive intermediates and can also convert tocopheroxyl radical into a-tocopherol to prevent the direct membrane damage (Li et al., 2012).

The wastewater effluents are the point source for ENPs; and the discharge of the upstream wastewater treatment plant highly affect the water quality of the downstream drinking water treatment (Zhang et al., 2019).
CNTs primarily interact with epithelial surfaces and induce toxicity without absorption across epithelial membranes (Petersen et al., 2011).

Other endocytosis pathways including caveolae/lipid raft-dependent endocytosis and macropinocytosis did not transport the ENPs for lysosomal degradation, but inside cell, particles remain in nano-form (Tangaa et al., 2016).

As ENPs have the tendency to bind with protein (protein-corona) and aggregate in saline solution so these are not excreted out of an organism’s body like regular contaminants via excretory organs (Lin et al., 2010).

Primary ENPs toxicity induction modes include but not limited to the release of ions with particles dissolution, oxidative stress, cellular protein injury, membrane and DNA damage (Das et al., 2018; Sonane et al., 2017; Zhao, He, Lu, & Duo, 2017).

Moreover, after internalization in cell positively charged ENPs has the affinity to bind with proteins, vitamins or other ion and localized in lysosome which trigger CeO2 (þ) oxidase activity due to acidic microenvironment (Collin et al., 2014).

Moreover, after intact ENPs tissue internalization in lower trophic level organisms, body surfaces adsorption, bio-accumulation in the gut lumen and subsequent transfer of ENPs from prey to predator is a novel scenario (Tangaa et al., 2016).
Au ENPs bio-accumulated in Daphnia magna when fed with contaminated algae (Lee et al., 2015).

Through the trophic level transfer of ENPs, different sub-lethal effects including changes in growth and development, lifespan reduction and impaired reproduction have been reported (Luo et al., 2016; Tangaa et al., 2016).

Bio-magnification through the food chain is considered to be dependent on both abiotic (ENPs properties, exposure condition of prey) and biotic factors (physiology of organisms, predator-prey relationship, food web structure, analyzed organ) (Judy et al., 2011; Luo et al., 2016).

For the purpose of efficient nano-waste handling, the categorization of nano-waste as a function of constituent material toxicity and exposure potency provide several benefits including effective waste treatment and disposal to mitigate the ENPs eco-toxicity hazardous (Bakiu, 2018).
Montmorillonite is 2:1 type clay with sheet-like structure, in which two layers of Si-tetrahedra sandwich one layer of Al-octahedra (Liu et al., 2017).

The hydrogen-bonding and Lewis acid-base interactions induced the aggregation of carbon dots (CDs) with soil minerals in addition to van der Waals and electrical double-layer forces and reduce the bioavailability of these carbon based ENMs (Liu et al., 2017).

Nano-materials bio-genic synthesis involved one step reduction and stabilization through biological routes relying on microbes, algae, plants or their derived products (biomolecules) using the principles of nano-bio-technology (Saratale et al., 2018).
Green synthesis approach can substantially reduce the use of toxic chemicals and solvents used in the conventional energy-intensive physical and chemical fabrication processes (Singh et al., 2018).

It reduced the bioavailability, uptake, and accumulation of CeO2, and Ag ENPs to soil fauna Oligochaeta (Enchytraeus albidus) and earthworm (Eisenia fetida) (Nyoka, Kanyile, Bredenhand, Prinsloo, & Voua Otomo, 2018; Servin et al., 2018).
biochar substantially reduced the uptake and bioaccumulation of Ag ENPs in the rice plants (Abbas et al., 2019).
) plants by immobilizing the ENPs with space shield effect and surface adsorption of released Cu2þ ions (Sima et al., 2017).

Other mechanisms of nano-pollutants bioavailability reduction through biochar addition involved the alternation in the pH of exposure medium which reduced the dissolution process of ENPs (Abbas et al., 2019).
Microbes degrade the ENPs in the environment especially carbon-based nano-materials with the secretion of extracellular enzymes and EPS (Schreiner et al., 2009; Zhang, Chen, & Alvarez, 2014).
For instance, white-rot basidiomycete fungi can enzymatically degrade the hydroxylated fullerol (C60 (OH)19-27) by the oxidation process and mineralized it to CO2 in 32weeks (Schreiner et al., 2009).

In a recent study, Zhang and coworkers (Zhang et al., 2014) have observed the degradation of close cage SWCNT structure either by the direct Mn3þ oxidation process or through the malonate mediated pathway with a naturally occurring extracellular enzyme manganese peroxidase (MnP).

During the degradation process of carbon-based nanomaterials, the length and diameter of materials reduced, carboxyl groups are added, and CO2 is produced (Schreiner et al., 2009; Zhang et al., 2014).

Existing conventional disposal methods of hyper-accumulated plants such as combustion, composting, incineration and landfilling, introduces secondary pollutants in the environmental compartments (air, soil and water bodies) (Rai et al., 2018).

A multifaceted approach should be adopted including advanced research, public awareness, integrated legislation, and technical assistance in periodical evaluation of nano-enabled products to obtain the maximum desirable benefits and keep the detrimental outcomes below the threshold level with the use of these products (Patil et al., 2016; Younis et al., 2018).

metadata.abstractText: The rapid development in nanotechnology and incorporation of engineered nano-particles (ENPs) in a wide range of consumer products releasing the massive quantities of ENPs in different environmental compartments. The released ENPs from nanoenabled products during their life cycle raising environmental health and safety issues. This review addresses the recent state of knowledge regarding the ENPs ecotoxicity to various organisms lying at different trophic levels. Studies show that reactive oxygen species (ROS) mediated oxidative stress is the primary mechanism of nano-toxicity, either through physical damage by direct contact or release of toxic ions after ENPs dissolution process. Moreover, ENPs uptake, transformation and toxicity on physiomorphological, biochemical and molecular levels in primary producers of terrestrial environment (plants) were also reviewed. Additionally, the intrinsic detoxification mechanism in plants in response to ENPs accumulation was also examined. In the end different sustainable approaches such as biogenic synthesis, clay minerals role, biochar application, bioremediation, and legislative measures are proposed for effective handling and treatment of nano-wastes to get the maximum benefits of nanotechnology with minimum negative outcomes.
